item.title: Apple's iOS 11 update ends support for iPhone 5 and 5C
item.description: Some older apps on newer devices will also stop working when the operating system is installed.

item.title: Sony sells one million VR headsets
item.description: Sales of the VR headset have exceeded expectation, says Sony.

item.title: Computers trained to spot fake online profiles
item.description: Social media users who lie about their age and gender may soon be spotted by computer algorithms.

item.title: Uber fires 20 staff after harassment investigation
item.description: Ride-hailing service sacks 20 staff over sexual harassment, bullying and other issues.

item.title: Uber and Lyft ordered to share data with San Francisco
item.description: The city attorney says he needs to ensure the ride-hailing firms are not creating "a public nuisance".

item.title: Security firm asks EU to investigate Microsoft
item.description: Kaspersky complains that Microsoft is driving Windows 10 users to its own anti-virus software.

item.title: Apple reveals HomePod smart speaker
item.description: The voice-activated loudspeaker is powered by the Siri virtual assistant.

item.title: Amazon to discount Prime for US families on welfare
item.description: American families on welfare or receiving food stamps will get Prime for less, says Amazon.

item.title: Harvard bars students for posting 'obscene memes'
item.description: Racial slurs and jokes about sexual abuse were being shared in a Facebook group for new entrants.

item.title: London attack: Politicians v the internet
item.description: Experts warn that tighter online regulation will not remove the "safe space" for extremist ideology.

item.title: US bitcoin conman hit with $12m fine
item.description: The fraudulent scheme netted the Connecticut conman about $20m, say US prosecutors.

item.title: Racial 'disparity' in police respect
item.description: Scientists use body camera footage to study how US police officers engage with people while on patrol.

item.title: US contractor Reality Winner arrested after NSA leak report
item.description: Reality Leigh Winner, 25, allegedly took classified material from a government facility in Georgia.

item.title: Messaging app Telegram centrepiece of IS social media strategy
item.description: The Islamic State group relies on encrypted messaging app Telegram to spread its message digitally.

item.title: Apple 'caught by Australian error 53 undercover sting'
item.description: Australian investigators claim to have received misleading information regarding Apple repairs.

item.title: London attack: Tech firms fight back in extremism row
item.description: Google, Facebook and Twitter say they are tackling extremism after Theresa May urges more regulation.

item.title: VR pioneer founds border security start-up
item.description: Sensors mounted on posts will be used to monitor activity around walls, fences and arenas.

item.title: Uber has refunded passengers after London Bridge terror attack
item.description: Criticised for increasing prices as people fled the London Bridge attack, Uber has now refunded passengers who used the taxi app.

item.title: Google to let publishers charge users for ad-blockers
item.description: The tech giant is also working on an ad-blocker of its own for the Chrome web browser.

item.title: Tech leaders defy Trump on climate deal
item.description: President Trump says the US will withdraw from the Paris climate accord - but US tech firms are backing it.

item.title: US can ask visa applicants for social media history
item.description: US visa applicants worldwide can now be asked for social media usernames going back five years.

item.title: YouTube clarifies 'hate speech' rules
item.description: The video-sharing site wants video-makers to know which content is considered "advertiser-friendly".

item.title: Facebook shareholders press management on fake news
item.description: The company has rebuffed a request for a report on the issue, pointing to steps it has already taken.

item.title: Putin: Patriotic Russians may be involved in hacking
item.description: "Patriotic" Russians might be engaged in hacking, their President suggests.

item.title: ViaSat-2: Satellite goliath goes into orbit
item.description: ViaSat-2 enters the record books as the most powerful commercial broadband spacecraft ever launched.

item.title: Why did 'power surge' hit BA computers?
item.description: BA's explanation for its systems' meltdown at the weekend has left many scratching their heads.

item.title: US military data found unprotected on Amazon web server
item.description: The agencies involved say no classified files were on the server or could be accessed using the data.

item.title: Password manager OneLogin hit by data breach
item.description: Customers are told "unauthorised access" has led to their encrypted data being compromised.

item.title: 'Cash for hacks' crowd-funding campaign abandoned
item.description: Security researchers cancel plans to buy undetected software security vulnerabilities from hackers.

item.title: Ethiopia blocks internet 'to stop exam cheats'
item.description: One government official claimed the blackout was designed to prevent online leaks of exam papers.

item.title: Edinburgh University blames a system error for 'failed degree' emails
item.description: Edinburgh University says no graduations have been cancelled and insists student data was not compromised.

item.title: The smart tap which aims to serve 'perfect' beer
item.description: A San Francisco company has created a smart beer tap that aims to pour you the "perfect" pint.

item.title: A closer look at Apple's Homepod voice-enabled speaker
item.description: Apple has announced Homepod, a new voice-controlled speaker. The device will compete with Amazon's Alexa and Google Home.

item.title: Hands-on with the new iPad Pro and iOS11
item.description: A hands-on with the new iPad Pro and some of the features Apple is adding to its mobile operating system, iOS. The announcement was made at Apple's annual developers' conference.

item.title: Stephen Fry on Facebook
item.description: Stephen Fry says Facebook needs to ensure its news sources are not "blatant lies or propaganda".

item.title: Snapchat Spectacles arrive in UK
item.description: Video-recording glasses go on sale in the UK, as the company behind Snapchat tries to diversify.

item.title: Google offers virtual museum tours and other news
item.description: BBC Click's Dan Simmons looks at some of the best of the week's technology news stories.

item.title: India launches 'monster' rocket
item.description: The rocket will give India an edge in the satellite market and it's prompted some big comparisons.

item.title: TVs in children's bedrooms 'increase risk of obesity'
item.description: Our screens might be getting flatter but our children are getting fatter, researchers say.

item.title: VR game Star Trek: Bridge Crew tested
item.description: BBC Click tries out the new virtual reality game Star Trek: Bridge Crew.

item.title: Estonia’s robot graffiti artists
item.description: Each drop of paint is sprayed individually building the picture dot by dot.

item.title: Volvo's autonomous refuse lorry and other tech news
item.description: BBC Click's Kathleen Hawkins looks at the best of the week's technology news.

item.title: How to beat security threats to 'internet of things'
item.description: Click talks to a cyber-security expert about how to protect your connected home appliances from hackers.

item.title: Baby bytes
item.description: Hundreds of apps give breastfeeding and baby advice to new mums, but are they any good?

item.title: Staylittle: Village cut off from web finally gets online
item.description: At a time when you can email from your phone, one village has remained in the "dark ages" with no mobile phone or broadband internet until now.

item.title: From videos to vlogs
item.description: In the 1980s, Jane Fonda sold millions of workout videos. Now anyone can be an online fitness guru.

item.title: Online politics
item.description: Political parties are suddenly spending much more money on targeted digital advertising on Facebook. Why?

item.title: Rights v robots
item.description: Artificial intelligence will have a huge impact on jobs - so are the parties still committed to it?

item.title: Voter change
item.description: More countries are using internet voting for elections. But does it encourage more people to vote - and is it safe?

item.title: Mapping a new frontier
item.description: Share Lab uses flow charts and data analysis to map one of the greatest forces shaping our world - Facebook.

item.title: New coins on the block
item.description: Why digital currencies are hitting record highs.

item.title: Cuban revolution
item.description: As the internet becomes more widespread in Cuba, online start-ups are emerging. But challenges remain.

item.title: WannaCry lessons
item.description: How can businesses protect themselves against future cyber-attacks?

item.title: Sex doll chat
item.description: The BBC visits a factory in California which is making a new AI-enabled sex doll called Harmony.

item.title: Skype gets Snapchat-style makeover
item.description: The popular video-calling app now lets people curate a 'daily story' - just like Snapchat.

item.title: Google Expedition brings 3D objects to classrooms
item.description: Google Expedition brings 3D objects to classrooms with augmented reality. The technology was shown off at Google I/O, the company's annual developers' conference in Silicon Valley.

item.title: HTC unveils 'squeezy' phone for selfies
item.description: The U11 has a pressure-sensitive edge that triggers the camera when squeezed.

item.title: Lost at the airport? This robot can help
item.description: The robot that helps people lost in the airport or the shopping mall.
